citation.article-title: Dissection of the genus Methylibium: reclassification of Methylibium fulvum as Rhizobacter fulvus comb. nov., Methylibium aquaticum as Piscinibacter aquaticus gen. nov., comb. nov. and Methylibium subsaxonicum as Rivibacter subsaxonicus gen. nov., comb. nov. and emended descriptions of the genera Rhizobacter and Methylibium
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Piscinibacter (Pi.sci′ni.bac′ter. L. fem. n. piscina a pond, cistern, tank, reservoir; N.L. masc. n. bacter a rod; N.L. masc. n. Piscinibacter a rod from a pond).
The description is taken from the species description of Methylibium aquaticum (Song & Cho, 2007), supplemented with data from this study.
Growth occurs at 15–42 °C and pH 6–10 and in 0–1 % NaCl; optimal growth is observed at 30 °C, pH 7.0 and in the absence of NaCl.
Chemoheterotrophic and facultatively aerobic; anaerobic growth is much slower than aerobic growth.
The major quinone type is Q-8.
The major cellular fatty acids are C16 : 1ω7c and/or iso-C15 : 0 2-OH and C16 : 0; C12 : 0 2-OH and C12 : 0 3-OH fatty acids are absent.
Major polyamines are 2-hydroxyputrescine, cadaverine and putrescine; no traces of spermine.
Major polar lipids are diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylglycerol and phosphatidylethanolamine; an unidentified phospholipid is present.
On the basis of 16S rRNA gene sequence comparison, the genus is a member of the order Burkholderiales, having Aquabacterium, Methylibium, Rivibacter and Rhizobacter as its closest neighbours.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain of the type species is 66.2 mol% (HPLC).
The type species is Piscinibacter aquaticus.
